Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision was reasonable and procedurally fair
Application_Facts: Applicants sought visas to attend a wedding in Canada; had employment, property, and children in Nigeria; limited travel history; sufficient financial considerations
Court_Ruling: Decision overturned; remanded for redetermination by a different officer
Defendant_Behavior: Visa officer disregarded strong evidence of ties to Nigeria; did not offer interview
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide opportunity for applicant to respond
Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted applicants' intention to return to Nigeria
Application_Basis: Demonstrating intent to leave Canada after authorized stay
Evidence_Assessed: Insufficient consideration of strong familial and economic ties to Nigeria
Governing_Rule: Applicants must prove they will leave Canada at the end of their stay under IRPA §20(1)(b)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to address or properly weigh key evidence of ties to Nigeria
Harm_Assessment: Unfair exclusion from Canada due to flawed decision-making process
Cause_Description: Applicants denied temporary resident visas to attend a wedding despite strong evidence of permanent ties to Nigeria
Evidence_Handling: Key evidence of ties to Nigeria was overlooked or dismissed without justification
Residency_Compliance: Applicants intended temporary stay; demonstrated compliance with residency requirements
Evidence_Assessment: Incomplete and biased evaluation of applicant's circumstances
Decision_Rationale: Doubt about return to Nigeria based on weak grounds; failure to consider countervailing evidence
Decision_Making_Body: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
